<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 170, 293]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 298, 379, 314]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 A Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 278, 905, 293]]<|/det|>
9702/42  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 299, 905, 314]]<|/det|>
May/June 2017  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[840, 320, 905, 335]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 339, 415, 355]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 359, 366, 375]]<|/det|>
No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 386, 407]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 718, 432]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 432, 324, 447]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 447, 504, 462]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 462, 504, 477]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 476, 380, 491]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 502, 255, 517]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 359, 543]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 543, 767, 558]]<|/det|>
You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 568, 604, 583]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 583, 759, 598]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 73, 126, 88]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 102, 670, 560]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81\mathrm{m s}^{- 2}\)

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 168, 88]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 107, 561, 144]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 163, 527, 180]]<|/det|>
\[W = \rho \Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 195, 537, 225]]<|/det|>
\[\phi = -\frac{Gm}{r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 235, 527, 252]]<|/det|>
\[\rho = \rho gh\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 262, 561, 294]]<|/det|>
\[\rho = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V}\langle c^2\rangle\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 305, 537, 321]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\omega^2 x\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 339, 615, 375]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \nu_0\cos \omega t\] \[\nu = \pm \omega \sqrt{(\chi_0^2 - x^2)}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 380, 537, 415]]<|/det|>
\[f_0 = \frac{f_s\nu}{\nu\pm\nu_s}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 425, 537, 459]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_0r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 467, 628, 485]]<|/det|>
\[1 / C = 1 / C_1 + 1 / C_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 500, 596, 518]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_1 + C_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 529, 527, 555]]<|/det|>
\[W = \frac{1}{2} QV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 570, 531, 587]]<|/det|>
\[I = A n v q\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 603, 596, 621]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 636, 628, 655]]<|/det|>
\[1 / R = 1 / R_{1} + 1 / R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 668, 520, 700]]<|/det|>
\[V_{\mathrm{H}} = \frac{BI}{ntq}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 714, 561, 732]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 747, 580, 766]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\exp (-\lambda t)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 777, 536, 811]]<|/det|>
\[\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_{\frac{1}{2}}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[295, 72, 700, 89]]<|/det|>

<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 210, 794, 229]]<|/det|>
The mass of a spherical comet of radius \(3.6 \text{km}\) is approximately \(1.0 \times 10^{13} \text{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 242, 181, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 242, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
Assuming that the comet has constant density, calculate the gravitational field strength on the surface of the comet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 433, 920, 452]]<|/det|>
<form>field strength = ............................................. Nkg\({}^{-1}\) [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 465, 181, 484]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 465, 710, 484]]<|/det|>
A probe having a weight of \(960 \text{N}\) on Earth lands on the comet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 480, 915, 499]]<|/det|>
Using your answer in (i), determine the weight of the probe on the surface of the comet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[510, 657, 920, 676]]<|/det|>
<form>weight = .................................................... N [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 99, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
The pressure \(p\) and volume \(V\) of an ideal gas are related to the density \(\rho\) of the gas by the expression

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 111, 556, 140]]<|/det|>
\[p = \frac{1}{3}\rho \langle c^2\rangle .\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 148, 181, 167]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 148, 524, 168]]<|/det|>
State what is meant by the symbol \(\langle c^2\rangle\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 242, 180, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 241, 920, 276]]<|/det|>
Use the expression to show that the mean kinetic energy \(E_{\mathrm{K}}\) of a gas molecule is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 282, 551, 311]]<|/det|>
\[E_{\mathrm{K}} = \frac{3}{2} kT\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 319, 824, 339]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is the Boltzmann constant and \(T\) is the thermodynamic temperature.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 530, 920, 549]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 562, 146, 580]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 562, 180, 580]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 562, 808, 580]]<|/det|>
An ideal gas containing \(1.0 \text{mol}\) of molecules is heated at constant volume.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 575, 920, 616]]<|/det|>
Use the expression in **(a)(ii)** to show that the thermal energy required to raise the temperature of the gas by \(1.0 \text{K}\) has a value of \(\frac{3}{2} R\), where \(R\) is the molar gas constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 808, 920, 826]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[388, 279, 920, 299]]<|/det|>
specific heat capacity = ............................................ \(\text{J} \text{kg}^{-1} \text{K}^{-1}\) [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 486, 918, 520]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 195, 870, 214]]<|/det|>
Two charged metal spheres A and B are situated in a vacuum, as illustrated in Fig. 6.1.

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 365, 532, 384]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 397, 722, 416]]<|/det|>
The shortest distance between the surfaces of the spheres is \(6.0 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 428, 920, 463]]<|/det|>
A movable point P lies along the line joining the centres of the two spheres, a distance \(x\) from the surface of sphere A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 475, 890, 494]]<|/det|>
The variation with distance \(x\) of the electric field strength \(E\) at point P is shown in Fig. 6.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[131, 508, 887, 866]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 285, 920, 320]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 549, 818, 567]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 564, 892, 583]]<|/det|>
The capacitor is then connected across a resistor for a short time. It is then disconnected.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 580, 730, 604]]<|/det|>
The energy stored in the capacitor is reduced to \(\frac{1}{16}\) of its initial value.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 613, 740, 632]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 861, 89]]<|/det|>
A Hall probe is placed near to one end of a current-carrying solenoid, as shown in Fig. 9.1.

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 338, 532, 356]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 9.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 370, 920, 404]]<|/det|>
The probe is rotated about the axis XY and is then held in a position so that the Hall voltage is maximum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 416, 146, 435]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 416, 260, 435]]<|/det|>
Explain why

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 448, 180, 467]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 448, 599, 467]]<|/det|>
a Hall probe is made from a thin slice of material,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 571, 180, 590]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 570, 920, 604]]<|/det|>
in order for consistent measurements of magnetic flux density to be made, the current in the probe must be constant.

<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 87, 662, 106]]<|/det|>
At angle \(\theta = 0\), the Hall voltage \(V_{\mathrm{H}}\) has maximum value \(V_{\mathrm{MAX}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 920, 152]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 490, 920, 524]]<|/det|>
Briefly describe two phenomena associated with the photoelectric effect that cannot be explained using a wave theory of light.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 536, 917, 556]]<|/det|>
1. ....................................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 599, 917, 616]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 676, 148, 694]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 676, 920, 709]]<|/det|>
The maximum energy \(E_{\mathrm{MAX}}\) of electrons emitted from a metal surface when illuminated by light of wavelength \(\lambda\) is given by the expression

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 715, 584, 749]]<|/det|>
\[E_{\mathrm{MAX}} = hc\left(\frac{1}{\lambda} -\frac{1}{\lambda_0}\right)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 753, 630, 771]]<|/det|>
where \(h\) is the Planck constant and \(c\) is the speed of light.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 785, 181, 803]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 785, 381, 803]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 814, 920, 833]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 78, 181, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 784, 102]]<|/det|>
The variation with \(\frac{1}{\lambda}\) of \(E_{\mathrm{MAX}}\) for the metal surface is shown in Fig. 10.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 107, 818, 445]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 459, 537, 479]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 10.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 584, 858, 604]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 761, 920, 781]]<|/det|>
<form>h = ....................................................... $J$ s [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 793, 144, 812]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 793, 514, 812]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 808, 824, 828]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 147, 564, 168]]<|/det|>
